Award.AwardTitle: Optimal Control and Sensorless Manipulation of Complex Ensemble Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to create a unified control-theoretic framework and develop computationally tractable methods for optimal control and sensorless manipulation of complex ensemble systems. Many practical engineering and biomedical applications involve controlling large ensembles of structurally similar dynamical systems by the use of a common control input. Constructing robust external inputs that steer an ensemble of systems to form a desired dynamical condition, such as synchrony, is of fundamental importance. The research will result in methods that are general enough to apply across disciplines and can be exploited in diverse applications ranging from quantum physics to neuroscience. The research approach progresses from a fundamental investigation of controllability of ensemble systems based on geometric control techniques to the development of an efficient optimization-free computational method for optimal ensemble control synthesis. Deliverables include distributed computational routines for optimal ensemble control design, experimental demonstration and validation of the designed controls, documentation of research results, engineering student education, and engineering research experiences for pre-service teachers.

If successful, the results of this research will substantially advance our understanding of complex ensemble systems and directly contribute to new developments in control and systems theory. It will also broaden seminal applications by enabling analytically and numerically tractable methods for optimal control designs in atom cooling, deep brain stimulation for Parkinson's disease, and electrochemistry. This achievement has great potential to make significant impacts on the advancement of quantum science and technology, network sciences, biology, and neuroscience. Undergraduate and graduate engineering students and pre-service teachers will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in multidisciplinary research, in particular gaining interactions with experimentalists. General public and pre-college K-12 students will also be engaged through, for example, Science Outreach Programs at Washington University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many cutting-edge applications in science and engineering involve simultaneous control of a population of structurally similar dynamical systems. Owing to the very large number of systems in the population, sensing or measuring for each individual system in the ensemble is in practice infeasible. Therefore, sensorless manipulation is desired to enable these applications. For example, designing and implementing electromagnetic pulses that excite an ensemble of nuclear spins is an indispensable step that triggers the applications of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for medical diagnosis. In brain stimulation, devising low power stimuli that desynchronize a population of pathologically synchronized neurons in the brain is the central idea for neurological treatment of Parkinson's disease and epilepsy. This project creates a unified control-theoretic framework and develops computationally tractable methods for optimal control and sensorless manipulation of complex ensemble systems.


By bridging ensemble systems theory with computational optimal control, general and versatile frameworks for robust control of ensemble systems have been constructed. The research substantially advances our understanding of complex ensemble systems and directly contribute to new developments in control and systems theory. Specifically, explicit controllability and reachability conditions, in term of the rank of the system and control matrices, for both continuous-time and discrete-time linear ensemble systems were established, which determined fundamental limits on the ability to manipulate the entire ensemble by the application of a common external input. These characterizations of fundamental control properties facilitated the development of control design paradigms to synthesize optimal controls. An effective optimization-free iterative computational method for optimal control design involving ensemble systems was then devised, and the convergence of the method was illustrated, which requires controllability and depends on the choice of the control weight matrix that offers convexity to the objective function. Moreover, the research has broadened seminal applications by enabling tractable methods for optimal control designs in diverse areas, including atom cooling, quantum computation, brain stimulation, circadian biology, and electrochemistry, in which the ability to control the time evolution and dynamic structures, e.g., synchrony, of ensemble systems is fundamental. The developed theoretical and numerical methods have been experimentally verified by designing optimal waveforms for entrainment of electrochemical macro- and micro-oscillators. The achievements of this research have the potential to make significant impacts on the advancement of quantum science and technology, network sciences, neuroscience, and brain medicine.


The project enhances the infrastructure for research and education through interdisciplinary investigation in quantum physics, neuroscience, and engineering. The research products and outcomes have been disseminated broadly to these scientific communities through publications, presentations at conferences, invited lectures and colloquia, and distributed computational routines to engage researchers around the world in this exciting new domain. The results of the proposed investigation have attracted students across disciplines to participate in the group seminars or term projects in the PI's research laboratory. This included the involvement of multiple undergraduate students and students from under-represented groups. In addition, independent study courses of ensemble control theory and its applications were developed, which offered basic and applied projects and rigorous training to the enrolled students who have minimal research experience. The outreach effort has also been made to engage the general public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through Science Outreach Programs at Washington University in St. Louis.
